text:
INTERVIEWER:
Hi.

Can you tell us your name and
what course you teach?

PROF.
WAITZ: My name is Ian Waitz and

I teach Unified Engineering.
INTERVIEWER:

Can you tell us a bit about the
class?

PROF.
WAITZ: It is a large class that

is put together by several
different faculty members.

We have taught it this way for
about 25 or 30 years.

INTERVIEWER:
In which department?

PROF.
WAITZ: In Aeronautics and

Astronautics.
And it provides education in

several of the important
disciplines for Aerospace

Engineering or Aeronautics and
Astronautics;

structures, fluids,
propulsion, thermodynamics,

computers and programming,
signals and systems and systems

engineering.
And those are all taught in an

integrated way over a year long
period.

And it is two semesters with
two subjects per semester,

so it is the equivalent of four
subjects put together in one.

INTERVIEWER:
And how many students take this

and what year are they?
PROF.

WAITZ: It is the entry-level
subject, or set of subjects for

our department,
so all students who come into

our department take it.
And they all take it as

sophomores primarily.
And this year we have about 75

students in it.
INTERVIEWER:

And I understand there has been
a bit of a team approach to

teaching the class.
Can you describe how that was

worked out?
PROF.

WAITZ: Yes.
It has evolved over time but we

are each allotted a certain
number of lectures of the total

number of lectures.
And for each lecture there is a

homework that goes with that.
And those lectures are all

interwoven with one another in a
certain order that makes some

sense in terms of the delivery
of the material.

And it is team taught.
But you show up and teach your

lectures and you tend to work
with the other people to

understand what their teaching
at the same time that you are

teaching.
You try and develop common

problems, common homework
problems that stress more than

one discipline so that you can
look at some of the

inner-relationships and
trade-offs between the different

disciplines.
INTERVIEWER:

OK.
So what do students do in

class?
Is it primarily lecture or do

they work in groups on projects?
PROF.

WAITZ: The classes are
lecture-based but we have

adopted a lot of active learning
strategies.

And we have done that for the
last several years.

There are two techniques that
we use predominantly.

One we call the Personal
Response System,

PRS.
It is a commercially available

product.
It is a small television

clicker.
I have got one here some place.

So this is the television
clicker.

And typically in a lecture
there will be one or two

questions that are asked,
sometimes three or four,

and the students respond to
these with these television

clickers.
And in real-time in the class

we get the responses back.
And we can look at graphs of

their responses.
So it is a short five or ten

minute lecture with a question.
Another short five or ten

minute lecture,
another question.

And that allows you in
real-time to understand what

they are having difficulty with
and what things they have made

progress on understanding and
adjust your lecture as you go.

That is the primary in-class
technique for engaging the

students.
We don't grade them on whether

or not they get the right
response.

We just grade them on whether
or not they have hit the button.

So it is part of the subject
grade.

There is an attendance score
which is calculated by how many

times they have pressed the
button out of the total number

of questions that are asked.
And, as I said,

it is two or three per lecture.
The second thing that we do for

each lecture is at the end we
finish the lectures a few

minutes early and we ask the
students to fill out the

muddiest part of the lecture
cards, so here are some from

lecture today,
where we ask them to take two

or three minutes and reflect on
the items that were discussed in

lecture and which part was the
least clear.

So the muddiest part of the
lecture.

And these are terrific.
With these you can find out,

in an anonymous way,
in the student's own words

which things they found to work
and which things that they found

to be difficult.
And often you find that items

that are tripping them up are
the symbols that you used or

that they have some lack of
understanding or some deficiency

in remember some prerequisite
subject material that you had

presumed that they had.
And getting this after each

lecture then you can take action
on these either by modifying

your next lecture or what I do
is respond to them all on the

subject webpage.
So I just write short answers

for each of the questions and
the students can go and look at

that.
So those are the two techniques

that we use within the lectures
for better feedback and for

active learning.
There is also a series of

laboratory exercises and systems
problems, but I presume you will

get an interview with Charles
Coleman or something to talk

about that aspect of the course.
INTERVIEWER:

But you had said that there are
laboratory assignments as well,

and there are other special
elements.

There are field trips and
things for this class.

PROF.
WAITZ: Yes, there are a variety

of special elements for Unified
as a whole.

For the lecture that I teach,
one of the things that I do is

wheel in an engine and teach in
front of the engine.

And it is a real engine.
It is a CFM56 which powers

Boeing 737 airplanes.
And when you're talking about

propulsion, having a couple
millions dollars worth of

hardware there to point to and
shake and have the students ask

questions about is very,
very helpful.

So there are elements like
that.

There are a lot of in-class
small demonstrations that each

of us do where we ask people to
work problems where they

estimate things or small
in-class experiments.

All of those are in the context
of these concept questions,

or many of them are where we
ask the students to observe an

experiment, to think about it
and to respond to some question

all intended to demonstrate
physical principles or to get

them to think about concepts in
the class.

INTERVIEWER:
OK.

Well, we want to thank you very
much for making your materials

available through MIT
OpenCourseWare.

Is there anything else you can
think of that you would like

someone to know about how
Unified is taught or anything

else that might not be obvious
from just viewing the course

materials online?
PROF.

WAITZ: No.
I would just say that it is

very important to us in
developing and delivering the

course materials that it be
viewed by the students in an

integrated way as a package so
that none of the sets of

materials were developed as
independent pieces on

thermodynamics or fluids but
they were developed within the

context of it being an
integrated course.

And we think that is very
important for educating students

in aeronautics and astronautics
that they do have this

integrated system level view of
how the pieces fit together.

And we prefer to start that
early by doing it all at once

early in their careers and then
have them take disciplinary

specialties later on rather than
vice versa.

So that is the only thing that
I would point out about it,

that it really has been
developed to be an integrative

learning environment.
INTERVIEWER:

OK.
Well, thank you very much for

your time.
PROF.
WAITZ: Pleasure.
